376.1.text: Triggered Abilities can usually be recognized by the word "when" followed by a game action or event; the word "at" followed by a point in time during the turn sequence; or the phrase “the [Nth] time” followed by a game action or event.

376.1.a.text: The phrases that identify triggered abilities do not always appear at the beginning of sentences or abilities.

376.1.b.text: If an ability triggers “the [Nth] time” something happens and that trigger condition is met multiple times simultaneously, the ability’s controller picks one of those instances to serve as the trigger condition. The ability triggers only once, due to the chosen condition.

376.2.text: Triggered Abilities have a Condition and an Effect.

376.2.b.text: The Effect is the Instruction that follows the comma after the Condition.

376.2.c.text: The Condition of a Trigger is evaluated after a potentially inciting event has been processed.

376.2.c.1.text: If a Game Object with a Triggered Ability that is active in a speciﬁc zone, it is evaluated and subsequently triggered if it enters that zone at the same time that its Trigger ’s condition is met.

376.2.c.2.text: A Game Object will not be able to successfully be able to evaluate its Trigger Condition , however, if it leaves the zone that its Trigger is active from at the same time that its Trigger is satisﬁed.

376.3.text: When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain.

376.3.a.text: Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn.

376.3.b.text: If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain.

376.3.b.1.text: If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order , each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.

376.4.text: Some Conditions are commonly used and structured in a way that explicitly deﬁnes their use and other properties of the Effect that is associated with it.

376.4.a.text: Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board.

376.4.a.1.text: These are commonly structured as “When you play me…” for Units and “When you play this…” for Gear.

376.4.a.2.text: These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ﬁnalized and enters the board.

376.4.a.3.text: These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Play Effects.

376.4.a.4.text: Abilities that trigger when another object is played are not considered Play Effects.

376.4.b.text: Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleﬁeld.

376.4.b.1.text: These are commonly structured as “When I conquer…” and “When you conquer…”

376.4.b.2.text: This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action.

376.4.b.2.a.text: The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleﬁeld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.

376.4.b.2.b.text: The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.

376.4.b.2.c.text: If the act of gaining one point from Conquering is negated or replaced in any way, the Conquer Effect will still trigger.

376.4.b.3.text: These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Conquer Effects.

376.4.c.text: Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleﬁeld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.

376.4.c.1.text: These are commonly structured as “When I hold…” or “When you hold…”

376.4.c.2.text: This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action.

376.4.c.2.a.text: The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleﬁeld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.

376.4.c.2.b.text: The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.

376.4.c.2.c.text: If the act of gaining one point from Holding is negated or replaced in any way, the Hold Effect will still trigger.

376.4.c.3.text: These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Hold Effects.

376.4.d.text: Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ﬁrst time during a combat.

376.4.d.1.text: These are commonly structured as “When I attack…”

376.4.d.2.text: These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat .

376.4.d.2.a.text: These triggers can only become fulﬁlled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Attacker designation multiple times in the same combat.

376.4.d.3.text: These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Attack Triggers.

376.4.e.text: Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ﬁrst time during a combat.

376.4.e.1.text: These are commonly structured as “When I defend…”

376.4.e.2.text: These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat .

376.4.e.2.a.text: These triggers can only become fulﬁlled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Defender designation multiple times in the same combat.

376.4.e.3.text: These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Defend Triggers.

377.1.text: Typically active while on the Board.

377.2.text: Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board.

378.text: Presence on Cards outside of the Board

378.1.text: Triggered Abilities on cards outside of the Board rely on the Information Level of the zone they are in.

378.2.text: Triggered Abilities outside of the Board will self-describe their context.

380.text: Reﬂexive Triggers are a type of Triggered Ability that create one or more Chain Items when their condition is met.

380.1.text: Reﬂexive Triggers can be recognized by the phrase “Do this:” or “Do one of the following:”.

380.1.a.text: “Do this” can be followed by “N times.” The Reﬂexive Trigger will thus be added to the chain N times when its condition is met.

380.2.text: Reﬂexive Triggers will be preceded by their conditions, if any. If no condition is present in the ability then the Reﬂexive Trigger will always be added to the Chain.

380.3.text: If present, the Condition of a Reﬂexive Trigger will follow the same format as a Triggered Ability.

381.1.text: A new ability is created and added to the chain as a Pending Item . See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.

381.2.text: If a Reﬂexive Trigger creates more than one Pending Item it creates them all in order, but does not go beyond the ﬁrst step of adding them to the Chain. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.

383.text: Delayed Abilities are a type of Ability whose trigger Condition identiﬁes a speciﬁc time during a turn or a speciﬁc event that can occur during a speciﬁc timeframe.

383.1.text: Delayed Abilities can be any other type of Ability , and contain all of the properties of that type in addition to the properties of Delayed Abilities.

383.2.text: Delayed Triggers are Triggered Abilities that can be recognized by describing a speciﬁc time of the turn, or by structuring a Triggered Ability with a speciﬁc frame of time as a restriction.

383.3.text: Delayed Replacements are Replacement Effects that can be recognized by specifying the effect they are replacing at a speciﬁc time, or “the [Nth] time” in the description of the effect as it resolves.

383.4.text: Delayed Passive Abilities are Passive Abilities that are applicable only during a speciﬁed window of time. The time that the Delayed Passive Ability applies will be recognized in the effect that initiates it.

384.text: Delayed Abilities will resolve or be active just like the ability they augment, but only during the speciﬁed time in the effect that created the Delayed Ability.

385.text: Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells . As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciﬁed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.

387.text: Playing or activating Abilities follows the same steps of playing cards.

388.text: Abilities when added to the Chain become Pending Items until they complete the steps of Playing.

388.1.text: When an Ability ﬁnishes the steps of playing it becomes a Chain Item just like a Spell.

388.2.text: When an Ability with the [Add] action is ﬁnalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item , like a Unit or Gear.

389.1.text: Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

389.2.text: If there is currently a game effect being resolved, continue resolving the game effect instead of continuing the following steps.

390.1.text: Make all choices required for this ability, such as targets, options, or other relevant decisions. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information

390.2.text: If legal options are not available for an Activated Ability, it is not legal to activate it.

390.3.text: If there are not enough options to make legal choices for a Triggered Ability that has been put on the chain, remove it from the Chain now. It ceases to be a Pending Item but never becomes a Chain Item.

390.3.a.text: This is not an Ability being countered.

390.3.b.text: If there are legal options to choose, the ability’s controller must choose them. They may not decline this stage of playing a Trigger.

391.1.text: Determine the base cost of the Ability.

391.1.a.text: Activated Abilities will have a cost listed before the “:” in their text.

391.1.b.text: Triggered Abilities will typically not have a base cost associated with them when placed on the chain due to their conditions.

391.2.text: Apply cost increases and decreases as a result of choices made in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

391.3.text: Apply any other cost increases or decreases as necessary. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

392.1.text: Pay costs as determined in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

392.2.text: At this stage, players may decline to pay for Triggered Abilities that have incurred a cost. If they do, the ability will cease being a Pending Item and be removed from the Chain. It never becomes a Chain Item.

392.2.a.text: This is not an Ability being countered.

393.1.text: Ensure that the Ability’s targets are still legal.

393.2.text: Ensure that the Ability ’s effect would not create an illegal state. If it would, resolve in the same way you would resolve a Card that creates an illegal state. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

394.1.text: This Ability is no longer Pending.

394.2.text: This Ability becomes a Chain Item.

394.3.text: If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, their controllers perform the remaining steps of playing now.

394.4.text: Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information.

394.5.text: Otherwise, execute the Ability just like a Spell , then clear the Chain Item from the Chain.

396.text: Game Actions are actions players may perform at any given time during the game.

397.text: A player, unless otherwise speciﬁed or prompted, may only perform actions on their turn.

398.text: There are two types of Game Actions:

398.1.a.text: A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.

398.1.b.text: A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions available to them during their turn.

398.1.b.1.text: As long as any conditions, if applicable, are met.

398.1.b.2.text: As long as any costs, if applicable, are paid.

398.1.b.3.text: As long as it does not result in any forbidden action being taken or game state being created.

398.2.a.text: A Limited Action is a game action that a spell, ability, or circumstance of the turn's progression causes the player to perform. A player cannot perform these actions at-will.

398.2.b.text:
These actions can only be taken when a player is instructed to do so as the execution of an effect or during their speciﬁed occasion during the turn.
Draw at any other time.

400.1.text: Drawing a card takes a single card from the top of the Main Deck and adds it to the player's Hand.

400.2.a.text: Each player draws 1 during the Draw Step of their Beginning Phase.

400.2.b.text: The player may draw cards when instructed to do so by other game effects.

400.3.text: This action, when instructed, is formatted as "Draw X."

400.4.text: If a player attempts to draw more cards than are available in their Main Deck , they do the following:

400.4.b.text: Perform a Burn Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.

400.4.c.text: Draw the remaining cards needed to complete the Draw action.

401.1.text: Exhausting is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as "spent."

401.1.a.text: To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Readying , so that the orientation of the card is lengthwise in front of you.

401.1.b.text: A Unit that is already Exhausted cannot be Exhausted again.

401.1.c.text: If a Unit is instructed to be Exhausted while it is already Exhausted , nothing additional happens.

401.2.text: "Exhausted" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.

401.3.a.text: Most Exhaust actions will be costs for Activated Abilities or Discretionary Actions.

401.4.text: When Exhausting is listed as a Cost , then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid.

401.5.text: In abilities, the Exhaust symbol represents the cost "Exhaust this" or "Exhaust me." It resembles a card turning sideways.

402.1.text: Readying is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as available for action.

402.1.a.text: To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Exhausting , so that it is vertically oriented in front of you.

402.1.b.text: A Unit that is already Ready cannot be Readied again.

402.1.c.text: If a Unit is instructed to be Readied while it is already Ready , nothing additional happens.

402.2.text: "Ready" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.

402.3.a.text: A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn.

402.3.b.text: The player may also Ready their Game Objects when effects or spells instruct them to do so.

403.1.text: Recycling cards is the action in which a player takes one or more cards from a speciﬁc zone and then puts it on the bottom of the corresponding deck.

403.1.a.text: Main Deck cards are Recycled to the Main Deck.

403.1.b.text: Runes are Recycled to the Rune Deck.

403.1.c.text: Each player Recycles cards to their own Main Deck and Rune Deck , regardless of which player is instructed to perform the Recycle action.

403.2.a.text: The player must Recycle cards from the speciﬁed zones when instructed to do so by game effects or costs.

403.3.text: When Recycling is listed as a Cost , the action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid.

403.4.text: When Recycling is part of an effect, a player must Recycle as many cards as possible from the speciﬁed zone or zones.

403.5.text: If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Main Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in a random order.

403.5.a.text: If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Rune Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in the order of their owner's choosing.

403.6.text: This action, when instructed, is sometimes formatted as " Recycle X from [Zone]." That means to take X cards of the instructed player's choice from the relevant zone and recycle them.

404.1.text: Spells, Units, Abilities, and other game effects may Deal Damage to units.

404.1.a.text: Assigning Damage during Combat Resolution is not Dealing Damage, but will cause Damage to be Dealt when assignment is complete.

404.1.b.text: To Deal Damage to Units, mark the speciﬁed amount of Damage on the Unit.

404.1.c.text: Damage is marked on each unit separately.

404.1.d.text: Damage can be Dealt to more than one Unit at the same time.

404.3.text: Dealing Damage is a Limited Action.

404.3.a.text: Assigning Damage causes Damage to be dealt outside of being directed to Deal Damage. See rule 437. Combat for more information.

404.4.text: Dealing can have the intrinsic property of Bonus Damage.

404.5.text: Bonus Damage is a property granted to the action of Dealing and alters the amount of Damage distributed by this action. See rule 712. Bonus Damage for more information.

404.6.text: Deal actions can originate from one or more sources.

404.6.a.text: If a game effect does not specify a source, the game effect describing the Deal action is the source.

404.6.b.text: If a game effect does specify a source, then that source is what is considered the origin of the Damage for this Deal action.

404.6.b.1.text: Units and Spells can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.

404.6.b.2.text: Abilities can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.

404.6.b.2.a.text: When an Ability is the source of Damage for a Deal action, it is in addition to the Spell or Unit that created that Ability.

404.6.b.3.text: When a spell or ability speciﬁes a Unit as the source of the Damage for the Deal action, it is not in addition to the spell or ability that speciﬁed it.

404.6.c.text: Damage Dealt as a result of being assigned during Combat has the Units as its source.

404.6.c.1.text: The Damage assigned, and subsequently Dealt , to attackers has the defenders as the source and vice versa.

404.7.text: Deal actions can distribute Damage as part of combat actions or non-combat actions.

405.1.text: Damage being cleared from Units is Healing.

405.1.a.text: If Damage is cleared for any reason it is considered Healing.

405.2.text: More than one Unit can be Healed at the same time.

405.3.a.text: Players may only Heal units when game effects instruct them to, or at speciﬁc points in the turn.

406.1.text: A player Plays cards by paying costs associated with that card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

406.2.a.text: As long as a player has the resources to pay the costs associated with the card, they may play cards.

406.3.text: Game effects may result in cards being played as part of their resolution.

406.3.a.text: This treats Play as a Limited Action.

406.3.b.text: Treat all steps of Play as normal, except as noted by the game effect creating this Limited Play Effect.

406.3.c.text: If there are no eligible cards to Play when instructed to Play in this manner like this, then nothing happens and resolution continues.

406.4.text: Some Abilities trigger when cards are played or otherwise check whether cards have been played.

406.4.a.text: These abilities trigger when the act of playing the card has been completed by the resolution of the card.

406.4.b.text: If a game effect prevents the resolution of the card—for

407.1.text: Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board.

407.2.a.text: Players may only move Game Objects when instructed to do so by Game Effects or costs.

407.2.b.text: The Standard Move inherent to Units may also cause Movement. See rule 142 for more information on the Standard Move .

407.3.text: The Standard Move inherent to Units is a Discretionary Action.

407.3.a.text: The Cost is Exhausting one or more Units.

407.3.b.text: The Effect is Moving those Unit.

408.1.text: Hiding a card is the act of placing a card facedown at a Battleﬁeld you control.

408.2.a.text: The Hidden keyword allows a player to pay a cost to Hide a card any time they have a Hidden card in their hand or Champion Zone and meet the prerequisites. See rule 737. Hidden for more information.

408.3.text: Cards that are facedown at Battleﬁelds have their gameplay properties and permissions deﬁned by the effect that put them there.

408.4.text:
If a facedown card would be put into a zone whose Privacy is Private or Secret , or if the game ends, its owner reveals it to all players.
See rule 127. Privacy for more information.

409.1.text: Discarding a card is moving it from a player's hand directly into their trash without activating or executing its normal rules text.

409.1.a.text: The player who is performing the action chooses which cards to send to their Trash , and may use Private Information to do so.

409.1.b.text: “When I am discarded” abilities or other Triggered Abilities that trigger on discarding are executed after discarding has occurred.

409.2.a.text: A player must Discard cards when instructed to do so by game effects or costs.

409.3.text: When Discarding is listed as a Cost , then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid.

409.4.text: When Discarding is part of an effect, then a player must Discard as many cards as possible from their hand. If instructed to discard more cards than they have in their hand, further discard instructions are ignored.

409.5.text: This action is formatted as "Discard X."

410.1.text: Stunning is the act of selecting one or more Units on the Board and rendering them Stunned.

410.1.a.text: Stunned is a binary state. A Unit is Stunned or it isn't.

410.1.a.1.text: A Stunned Unit can not be Stunned again.

410.1.a.2.text: Stunned Units lose the Stunned status at the beginning of the next Ending Step.

410.1.b.text: A Stunned Unit does not contribute its might to damage in combat.

410.1.c.text: A Stunned Unit must still have damage applied to it equal to, or greater than, its full might value to be killed.

410.2.a.text: Players may only Stun Units when directed to by Game Effects.

411.1.text: Revealing is the act of presenting a card to all players from a zone that one or more players do not have access to the information of.

411.1.a.text: Revealed is a temporary state and is not a zone.

411.1.a.1.text: Other cards, including the card being revealed, can reference the act of being Revealed.

411.1.a.2.text: Cards remain in the zone they are being Revealed from.

411.1.b.text: Unless otherwise described, Revealed cards do nothing else beyond become temporarily known information to all players.

411.2.a.text: Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects.

411.2.b.text: During the course of a game of Riftbound , a player may choose to show Private information to one or more other players. This does not count as revealing and does not trigger any effects that trigger when cards are revealed.

411.3.text: This action is formatted as "Reveal cards from [zone]."

411.4.text: Game Effects can manipulate or modify the cards Revealed while they are Revealed

411.4.a.text: While cards are Revealed , those cards can be further manipulated, or accessed. They can even have their destination modiﬁed for when the Reveal ends.

412.1.text: Countering is the act of negating the execution, activation, or otherwise playing of a card by a player.

412.1.a.text: A card that is Countered does nothing and is then placed in the Trash.

412.1.b.text: A card that is Countered is not considered to have been played.

412.1.c.text: Countering does not refund any costs paid to play a card.

412.2.a.text: Players may only Counter cards when directed to by Game Effects.

412.3.text: This action is formatted as " Counter [a card or ability on the chain]."

413.1.text: Bufﬁng is the action of placing a Buff counter on a Unit . See rule 701. Buffs for more information.

413.1.a.text: A Buff is also an object.

413.1.b.text: To Buff a unit, place a Buff Counter on it if it does not have one already

413.1.b.1.text: If the unit already has a Buff Counter on it, it does not get another one.

413.1.c.text: Units with Buff Counters can still be chosen for actions that Buff units, but will not be Buffed as part of the execution.

413.2.a.text: Players may only Buff units when Game Effects direct them to do so.

413.3.text: This action is formatted as " Buff [one or more units]." e.g., "Buff a unit." e.g., "Buff a friendly unit." e.g., "Buff two friendly units at the same battleﬁeld."

414.1.text: Banishing is the action of placing a card from any zone to Banishment. See 107.5. Banishment for more information.

414.2.text: When a card is Banished it is placed directly into the Banishment zone from its origin.

414.2.a.text: Banish is not a subset of Kill.

414.2.b.text: Banish is not a subset of Discard.

414.3.text: Cards and effects can refer to cards that were banished by the same object.

414.3.a.text: Separate instances of an object or effect banishing cards do not reference other banished cards by objects of the same name or effects originating from cards of the same name.

414.4.a.text: Players may only Banish cards or permanents when Game Effects direct them to do so.

414.5.text: This action is formatted as "Banish [one or more permanents or cards]." e.g., "Banish a card from your hand." e.g., "Banish 2 cards from your trash." e.g., "Look at the top 2 cards of your Main Deck. Draw one of them and banish the other."

415.1.text: Killing is the action of a Permanent going to the trash from the board.

415.1.a.text: This can be Active or Passive.

415.1.a.1.text: Active Kill is when the action is taken when instructed by a game effect or as a cost for a card or ability.

415.1.a.1.a.text: This is referred to as a Kill Instruction.

415.1.a.1.b.text: When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction , it ﬁrst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unit’s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ﬁnalized before completing this Kill Instruction .

415.1.a.2.text: Passive Kill is when the action is taken as a result of Lethal Damage or as a consequence for any other state.

415.2.text: When a permanent is killed it is placed directly in the trash from its place of origin.

415.2.a.text: It is only considered Killed if its origin was any zone on the board.

415.2.b.text: This is not a subset of Move.

415.3.a.text: Players may only Kill units when Game Effects direct them to do so.

415.4.text: Killing can also be the result of resolving a Cleanup.

415.5.text: Killing can be attributed to one or more Game Objects.

415.5.a.text: The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object.

415.5.b.text: A spell or ability that contains a Kill instruction is responsible for Killing the Unit or Gear.

415.5.c.text: When one or more Units is killed due to a Cleanup , the spell or ability that resolved immediately prior to that Cleanup that applied damage to the Unit or Units is responsible for that Kill action.

415.5.d.text: Abilities originating from Game Objects that are responsible for Kill Actions are responsible in addition to the Game Object that created them.

415.6.text: This action is formatted as "Kill [one or more permanents]." e.g., "Kill an enemy unit." e.g., "Kill this, [2]: Draw 1." e.g., "Kill all gear."

416.1.text: Adding is the action of putting resources into a player's Rune Pool.

416.2.text: Spells, triggered abilities, and activated abilities that Add resources ﬁnalize immediately.

416.2.a.text: Priority and Focus will not pass from Add abilities being ﬁnalized, and will resolve before any other outstanding items on the chain are ﬁnalized.

416.3.text: Activated abilities that Add resources and have the Reaction tag can be activated during the playing or resolution of other spells and abilities, any time that those spells or abilities require that resources be paid.

416.4.a.text: Players may only Add resources when Game Effects direct them to do so.

416.5.text: This action is formatted as "Add [one or more resources]." e.g., "Add [2]." means "Add 2 Energy." e.g., "[E]: Add [Y]." means "Add 1 Power of the Order domain." e.g., "Add [1][G]." means "Add 1 Energy and 1 Power of the Calm domain."

417.1.text: Channeling is the action of taking one or more Runes from the top of a player's Rune Deck and putting them on the board.

417.2.text: The Game Effect that instructs a player to channel 1 or more runes may specify the conditions or circumstances under which those runes enter the board.

417.3.a.text: Players may only channel runes when Game Effects direct them to do so.

417.4.text: This action is formatted as "Channel X rune(s)," optionally followed by conditions or stipulations. e.g., "Channel 1 rune." e.g., "When you play me, channel 1 rune exhausted." e.g., "Channel 2 runes exhausted. If you couldn't channel 2 runes this way, draw 1."

418.1.text: Burning Out is an action a player must perform if they attempt to move one or more cards from their Main Deck to any other zone in excess of the number of cards remaining in their Main Deck:

418.1.a.text: If a player must Draw cards in excess to the number of cards in their deck, they will Draw as many as possible, perform this action, then Draw the remaining amount instructed.

418.1.b.text: If a player must put one or more cards from their Main Deck in any other zone, such as the Trash , in excess of the number of cards in their deck they will do so as much as possible, perform this action, and then complete the remaining number required by the instruction.

418.1.c.text: If an instruction directs a player to look at or reveal cards in excess to the number of cards in a player’s Main Deck , that player looks at or Reveals as many as possible, but does not Burn Out, then proceeds with the rest of the instruction.

418.1.c.1.text: If there are insufﬁcient cards among the looked at or revealed cards to perform subsequent actions to the revealed or looked at cards, any further instructions are ignored. This does not cause a Burn Out , even if those instructions would cause those cards to change zones. Reminder: Cards are considered in the zone of origin while being looked at or revealed, in this case the Main Deck .

418.2.text: To Burn Out , a player does the following in sequence:

418.2.a.text: Performs as much of the prescribed action as possible.

418.2.b.text: Recycles their trash into their Main Deck. Reminder: When multiple cards are Recycled to the Main Deck at the same time, those cards must be randomized

418.2.c.text: Chooses an opponent to gain 1 point.

418.2.d.text: Completes the remainder of the action that caused them to burn out.

418.3.text: A player's Main Deck may remain empty as they Burn Out , usually because their trash is also empty. When they attempt to perform the original action again, it will cause another Burn Out .

418.3.a.text: Unless some effect intervenes, this will result in them burning out repeatedly, giving 1 point to an opponent each time, until an opponent passes the Victory Score and wins the game.

418.4.text: Burning Out is a Limited Action.

418.4.a.text: Players may only burn out when Game Effects direct them to do so.

418.5.text: Burning Out is a Replacement Effect. See rule 364. Replacement Effects for more information.

419.1.text: Doubling is the act of increasing a numeric attribute by an amount equal to that attribute’s current value.

419.1.a.text: This creates an effect that modulates that attribute by that speciﬁc amount for the duration speciﬁed by the Game Effect that instructed the player to perform this action.

419.2.a.text: Players may only Double when Game Effects direct them to do so.

420.1.text: c If both attributes are the same numeric value, Swapping has no effect.

420.1.a.text: Swapping creates two different effects that apply to each attribute. One that Increases one value and one that Decreases the other.

420.1.b.text: To accomplish this, determine the difference between these values and then apply an Increase for that amount to the lower value of the two attributes, and a Decrease of that amount to the higher value of the two attributes.

420.2.text: a Players may only swap when Game Effects direct them to do so.

421.1.text: Attaching is the act of linking two cards on the board together to combine their effects in some way. This causes one or more cards to become Attached and at least one card to become a Top-Most Card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.

421.1.a.text: Attaching affects two cards at once.

421.1.a.1.text: One card will be designated as the one being Attached , and thus become Attached. The other will become the Top-Most Card.

421.1.b.text: This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached.

421.1.b.1.text: In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card , they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects.

421.1.c.text: The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text.

421.1.d.text: The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it.

421.1.e.text: Attaching one or more cards will cause those cards’ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.

421.1.f.text: Attaching a card will cause it to Detach from any card to which it is currently Attached.

421.2.a.text: Players may only Attach cards when directed to by Game Effects.

421.3.text: Attaching cards does not inherently choose or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Attach cards may do so.

421.4.text: When a card Attaches to a card, its location becomes the same as the new Top-Most Card.

422.1.text: Detaching is the act of unlinking two cards that are currently linked through the act of Attaching . This causes one to cease being Attached , and potentially causes the other to cease being a Top-Most card.

422.1.a.text: Detaching affects only cards that are currently Attached to another card.

422.1.a.1.text: Game effects that instruct a player to Detach a card that is currently not Attached to anything will do nothing.

422.1.b.text: When one or more cards become Detached , they cease to be in the Attached state.

422.1.b.1.text: To represent this, these cards should no longer be placed under the card they were previously placed under as Top-Most Card.

422.1.b.2.text: If the Top-Most Card no longer has any cards Attached to it after this, it is no longer a Top-Most Card.

422.1.c.text: The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive.

422.1.d.text: The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text.

422.1.e.text: The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached.

422.2.a.text: Players may only Detach cards when directed to by Game Effects.

422.3.text: Detaching cards does not inherently choose, or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Detach cards may.

422.4.text: When a card Detaches from a Top-Most Card , its location is the same as the Top-Most Card from which it Detached.

422.4.a.text: If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleﬁeld , it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.

422.4.b.text: If the Attached card was Detached because the Top-Most Card changed zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, then the location that the Attached Card will Detach to is the last location the Top-Most Card was at before changing from a board zone to a non-board zone.

424.1.text: A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move , unless it is caused by a corrective Recall . See rule 407. Move for more information.

424.2.text: A card changing game zones does not in itself constitute a Move.

424.3.a.text: There is no state for Permanents between locations.

424.3.b.text: Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving.

424.3.c.text: Moving does not use the Chain , nor is it able to be Reacted to.

425.text: Moving is deﬁned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations.

425.1.text: The Origin is where the Permanent is starting from.

425.2.text: The Destination is where the Permanent is going to.

425.2.a.text: In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleﬁelds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds ( Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleﬁeld .

425.2.b.text: If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleﬁeld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged , it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.

425.3.text: Units are the only Permanents that can Move.

426.text: Players may choose to move their Units with the Standard Move. See rule 142. for more information on the Standard Move.

427.text: Spells , Abilities , or other effects may cause a Move to occur.

427.1.text: The source of the Move will provide details on any restrictions on legality for Destination.

427.2.text: Units cannot Move to a Battleﬁeld that already has units from 2 other players present by any means.

428.text: The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleﬁeld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved.

429.text: Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move.

429.1.text: A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleﬁeld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.

430.text: Units may cause Combat when they Move.

430.1.text: A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleﬁeld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.

431.text: When a Move action is complete, perform a Cleanup.

433.text: A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move.

434.1.text: They do not cause Triggered Abilities to trigger that are triggered by Move actions.

434.2.text: A Recall causes a Permanent to change locations.

434.3.text: A Recall cannot be prevented by actions and Game Effects that restrict or block Movement.

435.1.text: When an un-attached Gear is created or played at a battleﬁeld, or is at a battleﬁeld for any other reason, it is Recalled to its controller's base during the next Cleanup.

436.text: Recalls do not affect the state of the Permanent being recalled.

436.1.text: Unless otherwise stated by the source of the Recall , Damage, Exhausted Status, Buffed Status, and applied Layer alterations will all remain unaffected by a Recall .

438.text: A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain , and a Battleﬁeld has Units controlled by two opposing players.

439.text: Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleﬁeld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated.

439.1.text: If more than one Battleﬁeld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ﬁrst.

439.2.text:
If Staged Combats stop being Staged before the Steps of Combat are initiated, they are not resolved
or executed.

440.text: Combat can only occur between Units controlled by exactly two players.

440.1.text: In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleﬁelds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds ( Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleﬁeld. See rule 425.2.a. for more information on Invalid Destinations.

440.2.text: In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleﬁelds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,

440.2.a.text: If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleﬁeld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress , where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.

440.2.b.text: Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base , where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting.

440.3.text: All choices that would result in a Combat occurring between more than two players simultaneously are invalid and ineligible to be completed.

442.1.text: A Showdown opens at this time.

442.1.a.text: Establish who is Attacker and who is Defender.

442.1.a.1.text: The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleﬁeld. They gain the Attacker designation now.

442.1.a.1.a.text: This player gains Focus as this Showdown begins.

442.1.a.2.text: The Defender is the player who did not apply the Contested status to the Battleﬁeld. They gain the Defender designation now.

442.1.a.3.text: Units at the Contested Battleﬁeld controlled by the Attacker gain the Attacker designation now.

442.1.a.3.a.text: If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleﬁeld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present

442.1.a.4.text: Units at the Contested Battleﬁeld controlled by the Defender gain the Defender designation now.

442.1.a.4.a.text: If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleﬁeld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present

442.1.b.text: Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.

442.1.b.1.text: The Attacking player, who has Focus , places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ﬁrst, followed by all non- Defender players in Turn Order , followed by the Defending Player.

442.1.c.text: The State Closes if an Initial Chain was created.

442.1.c.1.text: Otherwise the Showdown continues, with the State Open as normal.

442.1.d.text: Players proceed with any play on the Chain as normal.

442.1.e.text: Focus does not pass upon closure of the Initial Chain, if any.

443.1.text: When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleﬁeld that was attacked, using their current Might.

443.1.a.text: The Combat Damage Step only occurs if both Attacking and Defending units remain at the location.

443.1.a.1.text: If neither Attacking Units nor Defending Units remain at this stage, the Combat Damage Step is skipped.

443.1.b.text: Sum the Might of all Attacking Units.

443.1.c.text: Sum the Might of all Defending Units.

443.1.d.text: Starting with the Attacker , each player assigns an amount of damage equal to their summed Might among the other's Units.

443.1.d.1.text: Assigning Damage is not Dealing Damage.

443.1.d.1.a.text: When all Damage is assigned, it will be Dealt simultaneously. These actions are not synonymous.

443.1.d.2.text: Abilities or effects may inﬂuence the order in which damage is assigned. Reminder: Lethal Damage is non-zero damage equaling or exceeding the Might of a Unit.

443.1.d.3.text: Units must have lethal damage assigned to them in full before damage is assigned to a different Unit.

443.1.d.4.text: Units cannot have more damage assigned to them than the minimum required to constitute lethal damage unless no further units remain to have damage assigned to them.

443.1.d.5.text: A player must obey all requirements and restrictions on damage assignment if able.

443.1.d.6.text: If multiple Units have abilities or effects that require a player to assign them damage with the same priority, that player may assign damage to those units in any order.

443.1.d.7.text: If a Unit has one or more Abilities or effects applying to it that demand it be assigned damage in a speciﬁc way that is exclusionary, then the assigning player chooses only one of those abilities to apply when assigning damage.

443.1.d.8.text: If there is more than one unit in which this situation applies to, each unit is dealt with individually. The assigning player chooses which ability or effect applies, and then resolves the assignment. If this creates a situation where now more than one unit must be assigned with the same priority, those units may be assigned damage in any order as normal within that priority.

443.1.d.9.text: If a unit cannot be dealt damage, then no amount of damage can be considered lethal. Such a unit is exempt from any considerations of mandatory assignment.

443.1.e.text: Deal Damage to each unit equal to the amount assigned to it.

444.1.a.2.text: Insert “2d. Recall Attackers present at the Battleﬁeld if Defenders are still present.” See rule 432. Recalls for more information.

444.1.a.3.text: Insert “2e. Remove Attacker and Defender Designation from all Units and Players. ”

444.2.text: 2. If no Showdown or Combat is staged at this location, the player with Units remaining here Establishes Control .

444.2.b.text: This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleﬁeld this turn. See rule 182. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1. for more information on Conquering.

444.2.c.text: This does not have to be the player that applied Contested to the Battleﬁeld.

444.2.d.text: If there are no Units remaining here controlled by any player, the Battleﬁeld becomes Uncontrolled.

446.text: A player Scores in one of two ways:

446.1.text: Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleﬁeld they did not yet Score this turn.

446.1.a.text: In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleﬁelds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiﬁed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.

446.1.b.text: A player will gain control of a Battleﬁeld after establishing Control by applying Contested ﬁrst.

446.2.text: Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleﬁeld during their Beginning Phase.

447.text: A player may only Score , from either method, once per Battleﬁeld per turn.

448.text: When a player Scores , two things occur:

448.1.text: The player earns up to one Point , depending on their current score.

448.1.a.text: The Final Point has additional restrictions.

448.1.a.1.text: Notably, points earned from sources that are not Conquer or Hold are not beholden to these restrictions.

448.1.b.text: When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score , and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play , the following occurs:

448.1.b.1.text: If the player has Scored through Hold , that player scores the Final Point.

448.1.b.2.text: If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleﬁeld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point . If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleﬁeld this turn, that player draws a card.

448.2.text: Trigger Score abilities at the Battleﬁeld that Scored.

448.2.a.text: Conquer abilities trigger at a Battleﬁeld that was Conquered.

448.2.b.text: Hold abilities trigger at a Battleﬁeld that was Held.

448.2.c.text: These will only trigger when the Battleﬁeld is Scored; I.E. These cannot be triggered more than once per turn for a player.

449.text: When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play , they Win the Game immediately.

451.text: Layers are the mechanism in which Game Effects alter the Traits, Intrinsic Abilities, or other properties of Game Objects.

452.1.text: Layers only serve to structure the application and order that Game Effects apply to Game Objects to maintain consistency.

453.text: The layers are applied repeatedly until all effects operating on objects have been applied once and no changes have been processed.

453.1.text: Layers are applied in sequence. Each effect in them is applied as soon as able, and only a single time across all sequences.

453.2.text: When a sequence of applications completes, recur the process, and evaluate each layer again applying any effects that may now be applicable.

453.3.text: The removal or disqualiﬁcation of an effect is separate from the application of the effect, but still can only be applied once.

454.text: Layers are applied in the following order:

454.1.a.text: This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace inherent traits of Game Objects. Name Super Type Type Tags Controller Cost Domain

454.1.a.1.text: Assignment of Might is dealt with in this layer.

454.1.b.text: One Game Object becoming a copy of another.

454.1.b.1.text: All Traits, including the Rules Text, replace or are added to those of the original Game Object as speciﬁed by the Game Effect directing the Copy. This is applied in this layer.

454.1.c.text: Effects for this layer can be identiﬁed by the phrase "become(s)", "give," "is," or "are" in the text.

454.2.a.text: This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace the abilities or rules text of Game Objects . Keywords Passive Abilities Appending rules text Removing rules text Duplicating Rules Text from one Game Object to another

454.2.b.text: Effects for this layer can be identiﬁed by the phrase "become(s)," "give," "lose(s)," "have," "has," "is," or "are" in the text.

454.2.c.text: Abilities of Effect Text of Attached cards are appended in this layer.

454.3.a.text: This layer deals with the mathematics of increasing and decreasing the numeric values of the traits of Game Objects. Might Energy Cost Power Cost

454.3.b.text: When an arithmetic effect has a limitation that applies, it is limited at the time of its application, and is “remembered” at that limited level for the duration of its effect. This process is called “snapshotting.”

454.3.c.text: Might Bonuses of Attached cards are applied in this layer.

454.3.d.text: This layer applies arithmetic in the following way.

454.3.d.1.text: b If there is a restriction or limitation to this increase, the limitation is “snapshotted” for the duration of the effect.

454.3.d.1.a.text: Positive values, or increases, to Might are applied ﬁrst.

454.3.d.2.a.text: Negative values, or decreases, to Might are applied last.

454.3.d.2.b.text: If there is a restriction or limitation to this decrease, the limitation is snapshotted for the duration of the effect.

455.text: If more than one effect applies to the same Game Object in the Same Layer , or to each other in the same layer, then both effects will apply but their order may be determined by Dependency.

455.1.a.text: Applying one of the effects alters the existence of the other; or

455.1.b.text: Applying one of the effects alters the number of objects the other effect can inﬂuence

455.1.c.text: Applying one of the effects alters the outcome when applying the other non- deterministically

456.text: To determine which effect Depends on another, determine which of the prior criteria applies, and then also which effect’s evaluation is altered by the sequence of applications. That effect is said to Depend on the other.

456.1.text: To resolve a dependency, the effects within the same layer that created the dependency must be applied such that: 1. Identify which effect Depends on the other within the Layer. 2. Apply the effect that is depended on ﬁrst. 3. Immediately apply the effect that Depends on the ﬁrst effect next.

457.text: If more than one effect applies in the same layer but no dependency is established, then Timestamp order is applied to the effects within that layer and sublayer

457.1.text: When an effect begins applying, it establishes a time for which it is compared against other Game Effects for purposes of resolving Layered effects as its Timestamp.

457.1.b.text: Timestamps are relative comparisons between effects and when they began applying to the game.

457.1.c.text: Timestamps are not referenced by Game Effects in any way. They are only used to ﬁnalize layered effects.

457.2.text: When Rules Text becomes Inactive for any reason, it loses its Timestamp. When it ceases to be Inactive, a new Timestamp is established.

457.3.text: Effects are applied such that the earliest Timestamp within each Layer and Sublayer applies ﬁrst, followed by other Effects in that Layer and Sublayer in chronological order.

459.text: There are multiple methods of playing Riftbound.

460.text: A Mode of Play must deﬁne several variables for the game.

460.1.text: Number of Players : How many people are playing the game.

460.2.text: Formation of Players : How the players are organized while playing.

460.2.a.text: This deﬁnes if a player is alone or on a team.

460.2.b.text: This deﬁnes the number of opponents.

460.3.text: Victory Score: The point total a player or team must reach to win.

460.3.a.text: Victory Scores can be any positive number.

460.4.text: Battleﬁeld Count: Determines how many Battleﬁelds are in play, contributed by players, during play.

460.4.a.text: This may inﬂuence deck building requirements in competitive settings.

460.4.b.text: This may involve utilizing less Battleﬁelds than there are players.

460.5.text: Setup: Any changes to initial setup required for this mode.

460.6.text: Format: Conditions to win or additional rules added over play.

460.7.text: First Turn Process: Adjustments to each player's ﬁrst turn.

460.8.a.text: If any, they will be appended here.

462.4.a.text:
Each player provides three (3) Battleﬁelds , included in their deck during deck building. Only
1 will be used, chosen during setup.

462.5.text: Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleﬁelds . The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleﬁelds are placed in the Battleﬁeld Zone.

462.6.text: Format: Best of 1. The ﬁrst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.

462.7.text: First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ﬁrst Channel Phase of the game.

463.4.a.text: Each player provides three (3) Battleﬁelds , included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup.

463.5.text: Setup: Each player selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleﬁelds . The other two are set aside and will not be used for this round of play. The selected Battleﬁelds are placed in the Battleﬁeld Zone . After this game, the Battleﬁelds that were used are to be removed and not selected again for this Match . One of the remaining Battleﬁelds that were set aside must be chosen instead.

463.6.text: Format: Best of 3. The ﬁrst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleﬁelds in play from the game, choose new Battleﬁelds from those set aside, and play again. The ﬁrst player to earn Two Set Points wins.

463.7.text: First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ﬁrst Channel Phase of the game.

464.4.a.text: Each player provides three (3) Battleﬁelds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup.

464.5.text: Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleﬁelds . The other two are discarded and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleﬁelds are placed between the three Players before play and will be used for this game.

464.6.text: Format: Best of 1. The ﬁrst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.

464.7.text: First Turn Process: The player going ﬁrst does not draw a card during their ﬁrst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ﬁrst Channel Phase of the game.

465.4.a.text: Each player provides three (3) Battleﬁelds , included in their deck during deck building.

465.4.b.text: The player who is taking the ﬁrst turn removes their Battleﬁelds. They will not be used.

465.5.text: Setup: Each player who is not going ﬁrst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleﬁelds . The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleﬁelds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game.

465.6.text: Format: Best of 1. The ﬁrst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.

465.7.text: First Turn Process: The player going ﬁrst does not draw a card during their ﬁrst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ﬁrst Channel Phase of the game.

466.4.a.text: Each player provides one (1) Battleﬁeld , included in their deck during deck building.

466.4.b.text: The player who is taking the ﬁrst turn removes their Battleﬁelds. They will not be used.

466.5.a.text: Each player who is not going ﬁrst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleﬁelds . The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleﬁelds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game.

466.5.b.1.text: The ﬁrst player will be followed by an opponent, then the ﬁrst player's teammate, then the ﬁrst opponent's teammate, and so on.

466.5.b.2.text: If allies are sitting across from each other, turn order proceeds clockwise as normal.

466.5.b.3.text: If allies are sitting next to each other, turn order is passed across the table.

466.6.text: Format: Best of 1. The ﬁrst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.

466.6.a.1.text: If one player Concedes , then the entire team loses.

466.6.a.2.text: If one player Loses, then the entire team loses.

466.6.a.3.text: If one player Wins , then the entire team wins.

466.7.text: First Turn Process: The player going ﬁrst does not draw a card during their ﬁrst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ﬁrst Channel Phase of the game.

466.8.a.text: Players may play spells during their Teammate's Turn.

466.8.b.text: Battleﬁelds controlled during the Beginning Phase of a player's turn by that player's teammate are disqualiﬁed from being scored by that Team, that turn.

466.8.c.1.text: Players may not Hide cards at Battleﬁelds controlled by their Teammate.

466.8.c.2.text: Players may not issue Standard Movement to their Teammate's Units.

466.8.d.text: Friendly describes controlled Game Objects by a player or their Teammate.

466.8.e.1.text: Players are not restricted in what they say to their Teammate, however.

466.8.e.1.a.text: Feel free to openly communicate, honestly or cryptically.

466.8.e.1.b.text: Revealing Cards is still a game action and cannot be done unless instructed. See rule 411. Reveal for more information.

466.8.f.text: The Final Point has an adjustment to the criteria when scoring.

466.8.f.1.text: When scoring the Final Point from Conquer , a player must Score each Battleﬁeld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turn’s Beginning Phase .

466.8.f.2.text: No other changes to Final Point restrictions.

466.8.g.text: Teammates may not utilize the same Champion Legend .

466.8.h.text: Teammates may not utilize the same Battleﬁelds .

650.text: A player may concede at any time.

651.text: When a player concedes, they are removed from the game in progress.

651.1.text: If only one other player is remaining after a player has conceded, the player remaining Wins.

651.2.text: If more than one player remains after a concession, follow the steps for the Removal of a Player.

651.3.text: Removal of a player involves them no longer being able to make choices or otherwise inﬂuence the game.

651.4.text: If the player has Teammates due to the Mode of Play , that player’s Teammates also lose and are removed from the game.

652.text: If the game continues, follow these steps for Removal of a Player.

652.1.text: Banish all permanents and runes they currently control and all permanents and runes they own.

652.2.text: Remove the Battleﬁeld they contributed to the game if it is in use.

652.2.a.text: If it was in use, replace it with a token battleﬁeld with no abilities.

652.2.b.text: Any units or hidden cards there do not move and are otherwise unaffected by this process.

652.2.c.text: If the removed battleﬁeld was applying any continuous effects, those continuous effects immediately cease, which may cause changes in the characteristics of units or hidden cards there.

652.3.text: Remove all cards they own from the game.

652.4.text: Counter all spells and abilities of all types controlled by the player that has conceded.

652.5.a.1.text: If the removed player was the Turn Player , play proceeds in Turn Order to the next available player in order.

652.5.b.1.text: If the removed player had Focus in a Showdown , the next Player in order receives Focus .

652.5.b.2.text: If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus , the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.

652.5.c.1.text: If the removed player had Priority during a Chain , the next Player in order receives Priority .

652.5.c.2.text: If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have passed Priority , then the most recent spell or ability on the Chain will resolve with Priority being re-established as appropriate for the state after the resolution of that spell or ability.

702.text: Buffs are objects placed on Units.

702.1.text: Buffs can be tracked with a buff reminder card from a Riftbound booster pack or with any spare object in your surroundings.

702.2.text: Buffs can be added or spent.

702.2.a.text: To Buff a Unit , a player chooses a Unit and then places a buff on it. That Unit is Buffed for as long as the buff remains on it.

702.2.b.text: Spending a Buff removes a single Buff counter from a Unit .

702.2.b.1.text: A buff cannot be spent from a Unit that does not have a buff.

702.2.b.2.text: A player can only spend buffs on units they control.

702.3.text: There can only be one Buff on a Unit at a time.

702.3.a.text: If a Buff is added, or instructed to be added, on a Unit that already has a Buff , it is not placed instead.

703.text: Each Buff individually contributes +1 Might to a Unit.

704.text: Buffs are Game Objects and may be referenced, counted, or targeted by other effects as speciﬁed.

705.text: If a Unit leaves play, remove all Buffs from it.

705.1.text: Champions do not retain Buffs in the Champion Zone, even if they return there somehow.

707.text: Mighty is a description that applies to some units. Other game effects can check whether a unit is Mighty.

708.text: A Unit "is Mighty" as long as its Might is 5 or greater.

709.text: A Unit "becomes Mighty" at the moment its Might changes from being less than 5 to being 5 or greater.

710.text: Units on the board are evaluated according to their current Might.

711.text: Units in Non-Board Zones are evaluated according to their inherent Might.

713.text: Bonus Damage is an intrinsic property that can be granted to Deal actions that inﬂuence the amount of Damage that the action is distributing.

714.text: If more than one instance of Bonus Damage is applied or granted to a Deal action, all instances are summed and applied once.

714.1.text: Bonus Damage can only be a positive value, and can only increase the amount of Damage being distributed.

714.2.text: If, for any reason, Bonus Damage would be a negative number, then no Bonus Damage is applied to the action.

715.text: Bonus Damage applies to the total damage Dealt by one instance of the action.

715.1.text: If the Deal action has a single target, the amount of Damage to that target will be increased by the Bonus Damage granted to it.

715.2.text: If the Deal action has multiple targets, the amount of Damage dealt to each target is increased by Bonus Damage individually and separately.

715.3.text: If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split . This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen.

717.text: Attaching is a limited action that causes cards to become linked to each other to combine their effects in some way. This causes one card to become Attached and the other to become A Top-Most Card. See rule 421 Attach for more information.

718.text: Attached is the state of a card being linked to another card in this way.

718.1.text: A card remains in this state until Detached.

718.2.text: While in this state, the card’s Rules Text is Inactive. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.

718.3.text: While in this state, Abilities in the card’s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card.

718.4.text: While in this state, the card’s Might Bonus modulates the Top-Most Card ’s Might by the value listed.

718.5.text: Attached cards still have all properties of being a card on the board while in this state.

718.5.a.text: Attached cards still have all Types and Tags while Attached.

718.5.b.text: Attached cards still can be chosen or targeted by game effects while Attached.

718.6.text: Attached cards cannot be moved separately from the Top-Most Card they are Attached to.

718.7.text: A card may be Attached only to a single Top-Most card at a time.

718.8.text: Attached cards may have different Controllers from their Top-Most card.

718.8.a.text: Changes in Control of the Top-Most card do not impact Control of Attached cards and vice versa.

718.8.b.text: An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Card ’s Might by its Might Bonus.

719.text: A Top-Most Card is a card that has one or more cards linked to it through the process of Attaching.

719.1.text: The Effect Text of all cards Attached to this card are appended to the Rules Text of this card for as long as they remain Attached.

719.2.text: This card ceases being a Top-Most Card when there are no longer any cards Attached to it.

719.3.text: A Top-Most Card and all cards Attached to it are at the same location.

719.3.a.text: When the Top-Most Card moves, all Attached cards move with it.

719.4.text: The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa.

719.5.text: When a Top-Most Card changes zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, all Attached cards Detach from it, remaining in their current zones.

719.5.a.text: The player that controls the Top-Most Card that changed zones decides the order these cards Detach in, and thus the order of any relevant effects that occur due to the Detach occurring.

721.1.text: Card text can occasionally be assigned to be ignored, disregarded, or otherwise rendered as not applicable during the course of play. This state is referred to as Inactive.

721.1.a.text: Text marked this way is not applied at all while in this state.

721.1.b.text: Inactive Abilities do not trigger, do not apply, and cannot be activated. Inactive instructions are not processed.

722.text: Inactive text is still present on cards.

722.1.text: Cards with Inactive text still have keywords for the sake of Game Effects that want to reference or see if a card has a keyword.

722.2.text: Game Effects that parse or interpret text to determine target eligibility may still parse Inactive text for the sake of eligibility.

723.text: Rules Text is never Inactive by default.

724.text: Effect Text is Inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached.

725.text: Inactive text can partially cease to be Inactive under speciﬁc circumstances and exceptions.

725.1.text: If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching , that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.

725.2.text: If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching , that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.

725.3.text: If an Attached card has an Equip ability, the Weaponmaster keyword can reference that Equip ability and any abilities that passively modify that Equip ability.

727.text: A Keyword is a speciﬁc term that appears on Cards that acts as a shorthand for a speciﬁc game effect, or ability of any variety.

727.1.text: A Keyword can be an ability.

727.2.text: Keywords can be identiﬁed by having a colored highlight behind them.

727.2.a.text: The color of the highlight has no effect on gameplay.

727.3.text: Keywords can be referenced or speciﬁed by other Game Effects.

727.3.a.1.text: The deﬁnition and rules of the speciﬁc Keyword will determine the behavior if a Keyword is granted while it is already present.

727.3.a.2.text: The effect that granted the Keyword will specify the duration for which it is granted.

727.3.a.3.text: If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.

727.3.b.1.text: The effect that removed the Keyword will specify the duration it is removed.

727.3.b.2.text: If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.

728.text: A card can have any number of Keywords.

729.text: Similar to other rules text, execute any effects of Keywords in the order listed when reading the card from top to bottom of the rules text.

731.1.a.text: Accelerate is functionally short for "As you play me, you may pay [1] and 1 Power as an additional cost. If you do, I enter ready."

731.1.a.1.text: If the unit has a single domain, the Power portion of the Accelerate cost can be paid only with a Power that matches the domain of the unit.

731.1.a.2.text: If the unit has no domain or more than one domain, the Power portion of the Accelerate cost can be paid with [A] (a Power of any domain).

731.2.text: Accelerate is an Optional Additional Cost to be paid as a player plays the unit with the ability.

731.2.a.text: Accelerate costs cannot be paid while the unit is on the board, only as part of the steps of playing a card.

731.3.text: Accelerate has no function while on the board.

731.4.text: Multiple instances of Accelerate are redundant.

731.5.text: Accelerate, and whether or not a unit has Accelerate, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

731.6.text: Accelerate inﬂuences the state of the unit entering the Board. It does not enter exhausted and then become ready.

731.6.a.text: Accelerate will not interact with, or trigger, abilities that are affected by units becoming ready.

732.1.a.text: It can be present on Spells , Units , Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities.

732.1.b.text: Action grants the corresponding card or effect permission to be played or activated during Showdowns, even when it is not the Controlling player's turn.

732.1.c.text: Action is functionally short for the following:

732.1.c.1.text: On Spells and Units: "This can be played during showdowns on any player's turn."

732.1.c.2.text: On Rune, Legend, or Permanent Abilities: "This can be activated during showdowns on any player's turn."

732.2.text: The card or effect with this keyword is not restricted to showdowns. This permission is inclusive of all other timings and options available to the ability as written or by default.

732.3.text: Action does not alter the function of any instruction of the corresponding card or effect it is on. It is only permission.

732.4.a.text: Whether or not a Game Object has Action is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

732.4.b.text: Whether or not a Spell has Action is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

732.4.c.text: Whether or not an Ability has Action is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

733.1.text: Assault is a Passive Ability keyword.

733.1.b.1.text: The X is referenced in the functional text of the ability.

733.1.b.2.text: The X is referred to as the Assault Value.

733.1.b.3.text: If X is omitted, it is presumed to be 1.

733.1.c.text: It is functionally short for "While I am an attacker, I have +X [M]."

733.1.d.text: Being an attacker means the Unit has gained the Attacker designation during Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.

733.1.d.1.text: Assault remains in effect as long as the Unit maintains the Attacker designation.

733.2.text: If a Unit has Assault or has been granted Assault and is granted Assault by an additional source, the Assault Value of all granted Assault keywords is summed.

733.3.text: Assault, and whether or not a unit has Assault, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

734.1.text: Deathknell is a Triggered Ability keyword.

734.1.b.1.text: [Effect] is the rules text for the speciﬁc instance of Deathknell. This is referred to as the Deathknell effect.

734.1.c.text: It is functionally short for "When I die, [Effect]."

734.1.c.1.text: [Effect] is the rules text of the Deathknell effect.

734.1.d.text: The Trigger for this effect is the Permanent being Killed and sent to the Trash.

734.1.d.1.text: If the Permanent with the effect is not sent to the Trash , for

734.1.d.2.text: The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup.

734.1.d.3.text: Before the card with Deathknell is moved to the Trash , note its location, its attributes, and any other details related to the effect of its Deathknell to process the trigger after it has been Finalized .

734.2.text: Each instance of Deathknell a Permanent may have will trigger separately.

734.2.a.text: The controller will choose the order to add these Triggers to the chain.

734.3.text: Deathknell, and whether or not a permanent has Deathknell, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

735.1.text: Deﬂect is a Passive Ability keyword.

735.1.b.1.text: The X is referenced in the functional text of the ability.

735.1.b.2.text: The X is referred to as the Deﬂect Value.

735.1.b.3.text: If X is omitted, it is presumed to be 1.

735.1.c.text: It is functionally short for "Spells and abilities an opponent controls that choose me cost an amount of Power equal to [Deﬂect Value] more to play as an additional cost."

735.1.c.1.text: The Power used to pay this cost may always be of any Domain.

735.1.d.text: It is an effect that imposes a Mandatory Additional Cost on Spells and Abilities that choose the permanent that has this ability. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.

735.2.text: If a Unit has Deﬂect, or has been granted Deﬂect, and is granted Deﬂect by an additional source, the Deﬂect Value of all granted Deﬂect keywords is summed.

735.3.text:
Deﬂect, and whether or not a permanent has Deﬂect, is a characteristic of the permanent and may
be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

736.1.text: Ganking is a Passive Ability keyword.

736.1.b.text: It is functionally short for "I may move to a battleﬁeld from another battleﬁeld."

736.1.c.text: It is a passive ability that adds permissions to the Unit's Standard Move.

736.1.c.1.text: It does not restrict or remove options from the Unit's Standard Move.

736.1.c.2.text: It does not have an activation cost.

736.1.c.3.text: It does not give additional abilities or activations of Movement, only new options for the Standard Move.

736.2.text: Multiple instances of Ganking are redundant.

736.3.text: Ganking, and whether or not a unit has Ganking, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.

737.1.text: Hidden is a keyword that acts as a prerequisite to perform the Hide Discretionary Action.

737.1.a.text: It is present on Spells, Units, and Gear.

737.1.b.text: It is functionally short for "While this card is in your hand or in the Champion Zone on your turn during an Open State, you may pay [A] to hide this facedown at a battleﬁeld you control that doesn't already have a facedown card hidden there for as long as you control that battleﬁeld. Beginning on the next turn, this gains [Reaction] and you may play this, ignoring its base cost."

737.1.c.text: It allows the player to take the Discretionary Action Hide .

737.1.c.1.text: Hide is not a subset of Play .

737.1.c.2.text: Hiding a card does not open a chain.

737.1.c.3.text: Playing a card from facedown (or "from Hidden") does open a chain.

737.1.d.text: Some choices made while playing a card from Hidden are restricted to the battleﬁeld where it was hidden. A card cannot be played from Hidden if it is a spell with no valid targets under these restrictions. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information.

737.1.d.1.text: A hidden unit must be played to that battleﬁeld.

737.1.d.2.text:
If a hidden spell or a play effect of a hidden permanent chooses any targets, those targets must be chosen from among options at that battleﬁeld, unless the ability explicitly restricts targeting in a way that makes this impossible.
restriction that can never be fulﬁlled by a unit at its battleﬁeld, its target may be chosen freely from among the available options.

737.1.d.3.text: If a hidden spell or a play effect of a hidden permanent causes you to play a unit, you must choose to play that unit at that battleﬁeld.

737.2.text: Abilities and instructions of hidden cards other than the choices listed above function as normal.
